data.title: Apple Music
data.meta_description: Listen to music by Dr. Dre on Apple Music. Find top songs and albums by Dr. Dre, including Still D.R.E. (feat. Snoop Dogg), No Diggity (feat. Dr. Dre & Queen Pen) and more.
data.text: When Dr. Dre got his first Grammy in 1994 (Best Rap Solo Performance, âLet Me Rideâ), the idea of mainstream audiences taking rap seriously was still pretty new. Not that rap wasnât popular: A few years earlier, N.W.A.âof which Dre was a key partâhad been the first hardcore rap group to have a No. 1 album on the Billboard charts (1991âs Efil4zaggin). But when it came to the kind of institutional respect that something like a Grammy confers, rap was still considered an insurrectionary fad: exciting, controversial and above all the kind of thing that mainstream America seemed to hope would go away. Not only did Dre (born Andre Young in Compton in 1965) help legitimise hip-hop in the cultural imagination, he changed the vocabulary of the music itself. Where early rap was built on breaksârecords excerpted and looped by a DJ in real timeâDreâs production on N.W.A.âs Straight Outta Compton (alongside other mid- and late-â80s work by Eric B., Rick Rubin, The Bomb Squad and others) brought about the era of the sampler, leading to tracks that were denser, harder and more reference-heavy. By 1992âs The Chronic (and Snoop Doggâs Doggystyle), heâd moved on to replicating the funk he loved with live instrumentation, drawing a line from â70s Black American music to a present where its messages of resilience and good times in the face of everything were especially resonant to a country shaken by race riots and sustained indifference towards its Black, urban populations. Listening to The Chronic could make you feel angrier, but it could make you feel tougher, too. By the time he was 30, Dre was already an elder statesman. Not only did he keep the music coming at his own pace (1999âs 2001, 2015âs Compton), he helped build careers for some of the most significant rappers of their generations, including 50 Cent, Eminem and Kendrick Lamar. And with the launch of his Beats by Dr. Dre headphones in the late 2000sâand the subsequent sale of the Beats brand to AppleâDre put himself in the rarified territory of JAY-Z and Kanye West: not just a hip-hop artist, but a businessperson, hustling, working and taking his cut.
